title: RNumbers

metadata.description: Learn about RNumbers with clear explanations and practical examples.

content_sections.title: Details
content_sections.content:
Numbers
There are three number types in R:
numeric
integer
complex
Variables of number types are created when you assign a value to them:
Example
x <- 10.5   # 
  numeric
y <- 10L    # integer
z <- 1i     # complex
Numeric
A
numeric
data type is the most common type 
in R, and contains any number with or without a decimal, like: 10.5, 55, 787:
Example
x <- 10.5
y <- 55
# Print values of x and y
x
y
# 
  Print the class name of x and y
class(x)
class(y)

Integer
Integers are numeric data without decimals. This is used when you are certain 
that you will never create a variable that should contain decimals. To create an
integer
variable, 
you must use the letter
L
after the integer value:
Example
x <- 1000L
y <- 55L
# Print values of x and y
x
y
# Print the class name of x and y
class(x)
class(y)

Complex
A
complex
number is written with an "
i
" as the imaginary part:
Example
x <- 3+5i
y <- 5i
# Print values of x and y
x
y
# Print the class name of x and y
class(x)
class(y)

Type Conversion
You can convert from one type to another with the following functions:
as.numeric()
as.integer()
as.complex()
Example
x <- 1L # integer
y <- 2 # numeric
# convert from integer to 
  numeric:
a <- as.numeric(x)
# convert from numeric to integer:
b 
  <- as.integer(y)
# print values of x and y
x
y
# print 
  the class name of a and b
class(a)
class(b)

★
+1

summary: This tutorial covers RNumbers concepts and techniques. You'll learn how to use RNumbers effectively, including key principles, common patterns, and practical examples. By the end of this tutorial, you'll have a solid understanding of RNumbers and how to apply it in your projects.
